H0.text: Moving at different rates is another explanation for why, after one hour in the sunlight, the hammer—whose shape and mass may affect the amount of heat it gains—is hotter than the screwdriver.

H1.text: Made of different materials, the hammer and screwdriver can absorb heat differently, which explains why after one hour the hammer is hotter than the screwdriver when placed side‑by‑side in sunlight.

H2.text: Used for different purposes is an explanation for why, after one hour in sunlight, the hammer is hotter than the screwdriver, aside from shape and mass differences that may affect the amount of heat each object gains.

H3.text: Picked up in different ways is another explanation for why, after one hour in sunlight, the hammer becomes hotter than the screwdriver, given that the shape and mass of each object may affect the amount of heat each object gains.

A4.text: In a 1780Ｕ letter... enabled him to rank seven different metals according to their thermal conductivities.

A5.text: System analysis by the lumped capacitance model is a common approximation in transient conduction that may be used whenever heat conduction within an object is much faster than heat conduction across the boundary of the object.

A6.text: Liquid water has one of the highest specific heat capacities among common substances, about 4184 J⋅kg−1⋅K−1 at 20 °C; but that of ice, just below 0 °C, is only 2093 J⋅kg−1⋅K−1.
